name: Scrambled Eggs
steps: 1) Crack eggs into a bowl and whisk lightly with salt.
2) Heat butter in a pan, pour in the eggs, and stir continuously until soft and fluffy.

name: Bhakri
steps: 1) Boil water until hot (not boiling vigorously). In a mixing bowl, add jowar flour and a pinch of salt if desired.
2) Gradually pour hot water into the flour while stirring with a spoon. Once slightly cool, knead with hands into a smooth, soft dough.
3) Divide the dough into equal portions and shape into balls.
4) Sprinkle dry jowar flour on the surface. Flatten one ball with your palms and gently roll into a thick circle, about 6–7 inches wide.
5) Heat a tawa or flat pan over medium heat. Place the bhakri on it and cook for 30–40 seconds until small bubbles appear.
6) Flip it and press gently with a cloth or spatula so it puffs up. Cook until brown spots appear on both sides.
7) Optionally, roast directly over flame for a few seconds to make it fluffier.
8) Brush lightly with ghee if desired and serve hot with zunka, thecha, or pitla.

name: Thecha
steps: 1) Heat 1 tbsp oil in a small pan on medium flame. Add cumin seeds (if using) and let them splutter.
2) Add green chilies and garlic cloves. Sauté for 3–4 minutes until the chilies blister and garlic turns slightly golden.
3) Remove from heat and allow to cool slightly.
4) In a mortar and pestle or grinder, crush the sautéed mixture coarsely along with roasted peanuts and salt. Do not make it too smooth — a coarse texture gives authentic taste.
5) Taste and adjust salt if needed. Optionally drizzle a few drops of raw groundnut oil for added aroma.
6) Serve immediately with bhakri, jowar roti, or simple dal-chawal. It can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

name: Bharli Vangi
steps: 1) Wash and slit each brinjal into a cross shape (keeping the stem intact) so they can be stuffed.
2) In a pan, dry roast grated coconut, sesame seeds, and peanuts until lightly golden. Cool and grind coarsely.
3) In a bowl, mix the ground mixture with onion, godā masala, red chili powder, turmeric, ginger-garlic paste, tamarind pulp, jaggery, and salt. Add a few drops of oil to bind the filling.
4) Stuff each brinjal carefully with this masala mixture. Keep any leftover stuffing aside.
5) Heat 3 tbsp oil in a heavy-bottomed pan or kadhai. Place the stuffed brinjals gently in the oil and sauté for 2–3 minutes on medium heat.
6) Add the leftover masala mixture to the pan and sprinkle 1/2 cup water. Cover and cook on low flame for 15–20 minutes, turning the brinjals occasionally until soft and well-cooked.
7) Once the oil separates and the masala thickens, turn off the heat.
8) Garnish with fresh coriander and serve hot with bhakri, chapati, or steamed rice.

name: Puran Poli

ingredients.name: water
ingredients.note: as required to knead the dough

steps: 1) Wash and soak chana dal for 30 minutes. Pressure cook with 2 cups of water until soft but not mushy (about 3–4 whistles). Drain excess water.

2) Transfer the cooked dal to a pan. Add grated jaggery and cook over medium heat, stirring continuously, until the mixture thickens and leaves the sides of the pan. This is the puran (sweet filling).
3) Add cardamom and nutmeg powder. Mix well and let it cool completely. Mash or blend lightly to get a smooth filling.
4) In a mixing bowl, combine whole wheat flour, maida, turmeric, salt, and 2 tbsp oil/ghee. Gradually add water to knead a soft, pliable dough. Cover and rest for 30 minutes.
5) Divide both dough and puran into equal lemon-sized portions.
6) Roll out one dough ball slightly, place a portion of puran in the center, and seal the edges to enclose the filling.
7) Gently roll it into a flat circle (6–7 inches) dusting with dry flour as needed.
8) Heat a tawa (griddle). Roast the poli on medium flame until golden brown spots appear on both sides, applying ghee while roasting.
9) Serve warm with a dollop of ghee or milk on the side. Puran Poli tastes best when slightly warm.

name: Appam with Vegetable Stew
steps: 1) Soak 2 cups of raw rice for 4–5 hours.
2) Drain and grind the soaked rice along with 0.5 cup grated coconut, 0.25 cup cooked rice, sugar, and water to a smooth batter.
3) Add 0.5 tsp yeast dissolved in 2 tbsp warm water to the batter and mix well.
4) Cover and ferment overnight or 8 hours until the batter doubles and becomes slightly bubbly.
5) Add salt before making appams and mix gently.
6) Heat an appachatti (appam pan), grease lightly with oil, and pour a ladleful of batter.
7) Swirl the pan so that the batter spreads around the edges with a thicker center.
8) Cover and cook on low heat for 2–3 minutes until the edges are crisp and the center is soft and cooked.
9) Remove the appam gently and keep warm.
10) To prepare the stew, heat 1 tbsp coconut oil in a pan and add sliced onions, green chilies, and ginger.
11) Sauté for a minute, then add curry leaves and mixed vegetables.
12) Add a pinch of salt and 1/2 cup water. Cover and cook until vegetables are tender.
13) Add thick coconut milk and pepper powder. Mix well and simmer on low flame for 2 minutes. Do not boil.
14) Turn off the heat and drizzle a few drops of coconut oil on top.
15) Serve hot appams with warm vegetable stew.

name: Pongal
steps: 1) Dry roast 0.5 cup moong dal in a pan for 3–4 minutes until it turns slightly golden and aromatic.
2) Wash 1 cup rice and add it to the roasted moong dal in a pressure cooker.
3) Pour 4 cups of water and add salt to taste.
4) Close the lid and pressure cook for 4–5 whistles on medium flame.
5) Once the pressure releases, open the cooker and mash the mixture lightly to get a soft, porridge-like texture.
6) In a separate pan, heat 3 tbsp ghee.
7) Add cumin seeds, crushed peppercorns, chopped ginger, and curry leaves. Sauté for 20–30 seconds.
8) Add cashew nuts and fry until golden brown.
9) Pour this tempering over the cooked rice-dal mixture and mix well.
10) Adjust consistency with hot water if needed and mix gently.
11) Serve hot with coconut chutney or sambar.

name: Zunka
steps: 1) Heat 2 tbsp oil in a kadhai or pan over medium flame. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
2) Add curry leaves and chopped onions. Sauté for 3–4 minutes until onions turn translucent.
3) Add turmeric powder, red chili powder, and salt. Mix well.
4) Reduce the heat to low. Sprinkle in the gram flour (besan) gradually while stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
5) Lightly sprinkle a few tablespoons of water to moisten the mixture. Keep stirring so the besan cooks evenly.
6) Continue cooking on low heat for 8–10 minutes, stirring every minute until the besan becomes dry, crumbly, and aromatic.
7) Turn off the heat. Garnish with chopped coriander leaves.
8) Serve hot with bhakri, roti, or rice and a side of thecha or pickle.

name: Upma
steps: 1) Dry roast 1 cup semolina on low heat for 5–6 minutes until aromatic and lightly golden. Transfer to a bowl and set aside.
2) Heat 2 tbsp oil or ghee in a pan on medium flame.
3) Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
4) Add urad dal, chana dal, and cashew nuts. Fry until they turn golden.
5) Add curry leaves, green chilies, and chopped ginger. Sauté for 20–30 seconds.
6) Add finely chopped onions and cook until they turn soft and translucent.
7) Add 2 cups of water and salt to taste. Bring it to a boil.
8) Once the water starts boiling, gradually add roasted semolina while stirring continuously to prevent lumps.
9) Reduce the flame to low and cook for 3–4 minutes until the water is absorbed and the mixture thickens.
10) Turn off the heat, add lemon juice if desired, and mix gently.
11) Garnish with chopped coriander and serve hot.

name: Kanda Bhaji
steps: 1) Mix sliced onions with gram flour, red chili powder, and salt.
2) Add little water as needed to form a thick coating batter.
3) Heat oil in a deep pan. Drop small portions of batter and fry until golden brown.
4) Serve hot with chutney or tea.

name: Masala Dosa
steps: 1) Wash and soak 2 cups rice, 0.5 cup urad dal, 2 tbsp chana dal, and 0.5 tsp fenugreek seeds separately for 5–6 hours.
2) Grind the urad dal into a fluffy batter with little water, then grind the rice and chana dal mixture coarsely.
3) Combine both batters, mix well, and let it ferment overnight or 8–10 hours until doubled in volume.
4) Add salt to the fermented batter and mix gently.
5) To prepare the potato masala, heat 1 tbsp oil in a pan, add mustard seeds, and let them splutter.
6) Add curry leaves, green chilies, and grated ginger. Sauté for a few seconds.
7) Add sliced onions and cook until translucent.
8) Add turmeric powder and the boiled, mashed potatoes. Mix well and add little water if needed.
9) Cook for 3–4 minutes, add salt to taste, and turn off the heat. The masala is ready.
10) Heat a non-stick or cast-iron tawa. Pour a ladleful of batter in the center and spread it thin in a circular motion.
11) Drizzle some oil or ghee around the edges and cook until golden and crisp.
12) Place a spoonful of potato masala in the center, fold the dosa, and serve hot.
13) Serve with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Tomato Saar
steps: 1) Boil chopped tomatoes with 1 cup of water until soft. Blend into a smooth puree.
2) Heat ghee in a pan, add cumin seeds and crushed garlic; sauté until fragrant.
3) Pour in the tomato puree, add salt, and simmer for 5 minutes.
4) Serve hot with rice or sip as a light soup.

name: Batata Bhaji
steps: 1) Heat oil in a pan over medium flame. Add mustard seeds and let them splutter.
2) Add green chilies and sauté for a few seconds.
3) Add turmeric powder and mix quickly.
4) Add boiled diced potatoes and salt. Mix well.
5) Cook for 3–4 minutes while stirring gently. Serve hot with chapati or poori.

name: Medu Vada
steps: 1) Wash and soak 1 cup urad dal in enough water for 4 hours.
2) Drain and grind the soaked dal with minimal water into a thick, fluffy batter.
3) Beat the batter with your hand or spoon for 2–3 minutes to incorporate air and make it light.
4) Add finely chopped green chilies, ginger, curry leaves, crushed pepper, onion (optional), and salt to the batter. Mix well.
5) Heat oil in a deep frying pan on medium flame until hot.
6) Wet your palms, take a small portion of batter, shape it into a doughnut with a hole in the center, and carefully slide it into the oil.
7) Fry 3–4 vadas at a time until golden brown and crisp on both sides.
8) Remove onto absorbent paper to drain excess oil.
9) Serve hot with coconut chutney and sambar.

name: Idli
steps: 1) Rinse the idli rice and urad dal separately 2–3 times. Soak rice with fenugreek seeds in enough water for 6 hours. Soak urad dal separately for 4 hours.
2) Drain the soaked urad dal and grind it with a little water until smooth, light, and fluffy. Transfer to a large bowl.
3) Drain the rice and grind it with just enough water to make a slightly coarse batter. Combine both batters in a large vessel and mix well with your hand.
4) Cover and ferment the batter in a warm place for 8–12 hours, or until it doubles in volume and turns slightly airy.
5) Once fermented, gently stir in salt. Do not overmix or deflate the batter.
6) Grease idli moulds with a little oil and pour the batter into each mould, filling about ¾ of the way.
7) Steam in an idli steamer or pressure cooker (without the whistle) for 10–12 minutes on medium heat until a toothpick inserted comes out clean.
8) Remove the moulds and let them rest for 2–3 minutes. Then unmould the idlis using a wet spoon.
9) Serve hot with coconut chutney, sambar, or milagai podi.

name: Kanda Pohe
steps: 1) Preparation: Place 2 cups of thick poha in a large sieve or colander. Rinse gently under running water for 10–15 seconds. Do not soak. Let it sit for 10 minutes to soften naturally. After resting, sprinkle a few tablespoons of water if it feels dry. Mix in salt, sugar (if using), and turmeric powder directly into the poha and fluff with a spoon.
2) Tempering: Heat 2 tbsp oil in a heavy-bottomed kadhai or non-stick pan over medium heat. Add 3 tbsp peanuts and roast them until golden and crisp. Remove and set aside.
3) In the same oil, add 0.5 tsp mustard seeds. When they start to pop, add curry leaves and green chilies. Sauté for 15–20 seconds until fragrant.
4) Add the chopped onions and cook for 3–4 minutes until they turn translucent (not browned).
5) Add the softened poha mixture and gently toss everything together using a flat spatula. Add roasted peanuts back in. Mix well but avoid breaking the poha flakes.
6) Cover and steam on low heat for 2–3 minutes. This allows the flavors to combine and the poha to become fluffy.
7) Turn off the heat. Add lemon juice and chopped coriander. Mix lightly.
8) Garnish with grated coconut (optional) and serve hot immediately with extra lemon wedges and a cup of hot chai.

name: Pav Bhaji

ingredients.name: homemade pav bhaji masala - whole spices
ingredients.note: 1 tbsp coriander seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp fennel seeds, 4-5 black peppercorns, 3-4 dried red chilies, 1/2 inch cinnamon, 2 cloves, 1 bay leaf, 1/2 tsp dry mango powder (amchur) optional

steps: 1) Make the masala from scratch (optional but recommended): In a small dry pan on medium heat, toast 1 tbsp coriander seeds, 1 tsp cumin seeds, 1/2 tsp fennel seeds, 4–5 black peppercorns, 3 dried red chilies, 1/2 inch cinnamon stick, 2 cloves and 1 bay leaf for 2–3 minutes until fragrant. Cool, then grind to a fine powder. Mix in 1 tsp amchur (dry mango powder) if using. Store — this yields about 2–3 tbsp of fresh masala.

2) Prep vegetables: Peel and roughly chop potatoes and carrot. Break cauliflower into small florets. Finely chop 1 onion for bhaji and thinly slice the other (for faster cooking you can keep both chopped). Roughly chop tomatoes. Crush garlic and grate or finely chop ginger. Finely chop coriander and slit the green chili.

3) Par-cook root vegetables: In a pressure cooker or large pot, add potatoes, cauliflower, carrot and peas with 1/2 tsp salt and enough water to cover. Cook until soft (2 whistles in a cooker or 12–15 minutes simmer). Drain and reserve the cooking liquid. Coarsely mash the cooked vegetables with a potato masher — leave it slightly coarse (not fully smooth).

4) Cook the bhaji base: In a heavy-bottomed pan or kadhai, heat 2 tbsp butter + 1 tbsp oil on medium heat (oil prevents butter from burning). Add 0.5 tsp cumin seeds and let them sizzle for a few seconds. Add the finely chopped onion and sauté until translucent and beginning to brown (6–8 minutes).

5) Add aromatics and tomatoes: Add crushed garlic, chopped ginger and slit green chili. Sauté 1–2 minutes until raw smell goes. Add the chopped tomatoes and a pinch of salt; cook until tomatoes are soft and oil starts to separate (8–10 minutes). You can mash tomatoes with the back of a spoon while cooking.

6) Spice it: Add 1–2 tsp of the freshly ground pav bhaji masala (or 2 tbsp if using store-bought), 1 tsp red chilli powder, 1 tsp coriander powder and 1/4 tsp turmeric. Cook the spices with the tomato-onion mixture for 1–2 minutes so the raw spice taste disappears.

7) Combine vegetables and simmer: Add the mashed vegetables to the pan. Mix thoroughly. Add 1 cup of reserved cooking liquid (or water) to loosen the mixture. Bring to a gentle boil, then reduce heat and simmer, mashing the mixture against the side of the pan with a masher to make a smooth-but-textured gravy. Add salt to taste.

8) Finish with butter and adjust: Add remaining 2 tbsp butter and 1 tsp kasuri methi (crushed) if using. Simmer on low for 8–10 minutes, stirring and mashing occasionally. If bhaji is too thick, add a little hot water. Taste and adjust spices, salt and lemon.

9) Toast the pav: Heat a flat tawa or skillet. Slice pav horizontally (not all the way through). Add a knob of butter and place pav on tawa cut-side down, press lightly and toast until golden and crisp on both sides. For extra flavor, sprinkle a tiny pinch of pav bhaji masala on the butter before toasting.

10) Serve: Transfer bhaji to a serving bowl, garnish generously with chopped coriander and a knob of butter on top. Serve hot with toasted buttered pav, lemon wedges and finely chopped onions on the side.
11) Vegan option: Replace butter with vegan butter or extra oil. Reduce or omit kasuri methi if unavailable.
12) Storage & reheating: Store bhaji in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days. Reheat on low with a splash of water and a pat of butter or oil to restore richness.
13) Scaling: This recipe scales well — double quantities for a larger crowd. If using store-bought pav bhaji masala, start with 2 tbsp and adjust to taste.
